The terms "board of commissioners," "board," and "governing authority" means the board of commissioners of the Heard County, Georgia. Code. The term "Code" refers to this Code of Ordinances of Heard County, Georgia. Computation of time. When a number of days is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, only the first and last day shall be counted. If the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action shall fall on a public or legal holiday as set forth in state law, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following business day to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, an intermediate Saturday, Sunday, and legal holiday shall be excluded in the computation. Conjunctions. Where a provisions involves two or more items, conditions, provisions, or events connected by any of the conjunctions "and," "or," "either... or," or "neither... nor," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows, provided that in appropriate cases the terms "and" and "or" are interchangeable: (1) The term "and" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. (2) The term "or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events may apply singly or in any combination. (3) The terms "either... or" and "neither... nor" indicate that the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events shall apply singly, but not in combination. County. The term "the county" or "this county" means Heard County, Georgia. Where appropriate, it shall also mean duly authorized officials, officers, and employees of the county. Court. The term "court" means the magistrate's court of the county. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or other officer of the county to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize such department head or officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to the required act or perform the required duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. Department, board, committee, commission, authority, agency. The name or title of any department, board, committee, commission, authority, or agency, unless specifically stated otherwise, shall be read as though the words "of Heard County, Georgia" were added thereto. Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be implied to female and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than any general provisions imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be applicable. Joint authority. Whenever a joint authority is given to three or more persons or officers, it shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of them. Keeper, proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean and include persons as the term "person" is defined herein, whether acting by themselves or through an agent or employee. May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive. Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. Number. The singular number includes the plural and the plural number shall include the singular. O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." refers to the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Oath. The word "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law or county Charter, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "affirm" and "affirmed" shall be equivalent to the terms "swear" or "sworn." Officials or officers. Whenever reference is made to officials or other county agents by title only, such reference shall be read as though followed by the term "of Heard County, Georgia". Ordinance. The term "ordinance" means a legislative act of the county of a general and permanent nature. Owner. The term "owner," when applied to a building or to land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. Person. The term "person" includes a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization, and any other group action as a unit, as well as an individual. Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every type of property except real property as herein defined. Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. Property. The term "property" includes real, personal, and mixed estates and interests. Public place. The term "public place" means any park, cemetery, shopping center, schoolyard, or open space adjacent thereto, or any area available accessible to the public, regardless of whether privately or publicly owned, and any place that the public is invited or permitted to go or to congregate. Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements, and hereditaments. Reasonable time or reasonable notice. The term "reasonable time" or "reasonable notice" means only such time as may be necessary for the prompt performance of the act required. Resolution. The term "resolution" means a legislative act of the county board of commissioners of a special or temporary character. Shall. The term "shall" is mandatory. Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, but shall not include any unimproved area between the curbline and improved walkways. Signature, subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark intended as such when the person cannot write. State. The term "state" or "this state" means the State of Georgia. Statute. The term "statute," unless otherwise specifically stated, refers to the indicated portion of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Street. The term "street" means and includes any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, viaduct or bridge, and the approaches thereto, within the county. Tenant or occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," when applied to a building or to land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. Tense. Words used in the present or past tense includes the future as well as the present and past. Week. The term "week" means seven days. Will. The term "will" is to be construed as being mandatory. Writing or written. The term "writing" or "written" includes printing and any other mode of representing words and letters. Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. State law reference— Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1 et seq. Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines, notes and references. (a) The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (b) The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Cross references and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. (c) All references to chapters, articles, or sections are to the chapters, articles, and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. Sec. 1-5. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect. Sec. 1-6. - Severability. It is the intention of the board of commissioners that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code is declared unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, the unconstitutionality of that portion of this Code shall not affect the remaining clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances. (a) Numbering; omission of repealed pages. All ordinances passed subsequent to the passage of the ordinances originally included herein that amend, repeal, or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and added hereto. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. (b) Language used for amendment of existing provisions. Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances of Heard County, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The provision may then be set out in full as desired. (c) Language used for insertion of new language. In the event a new section not theretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of Heard County, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered ____________, which said section (or article or chapter) reads as follows:…." The new section (or article or chapter) may then be set out in full as desired. (d) Designation of provisions repealed. All sections, articles, chapters, or provisions desired to be repealed shall be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. Sec. 1-8. - Procedure for supplementation of Code. (a) By whom performed; scope. By contract with outside entities or by county personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the board of commissioners. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the board of commissioners or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. (b) Authority of codifier. When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary, to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ through ____________" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. Sec. 1-9. - General penalty; continuing violations; abatement of nuisances. (a) Maximum fines and imprisonment; labor on public works. Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the county amending this Code, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such Code, ordinance or resolution the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor in this Code or by general law, the violation shall be punishable: (1) By a fine not to exceed $1,000.00; (2) By imprisonment for a period not to exceed six months; (3) At labor on the roads and streets or other public works of the county for not more than six months; or (4) Any one or more of any of the foregoing. (b) Imposition of penalties provided by general law. If a specific penalty is provided by general law, the violation shall be punished by any amount deemed appropriate by the court up to and including the maximum penalty provided by the applicable general law. (c) Continuing violation. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance or resolution shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (d) Abatement of public nuisances. In addition to all other penalties provided in this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by the county, as provided by law. (e) Restitution. If any person is convicted of a violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance, law, or regulation of the county, the court, office, or tribunal sitting in judgment shall have the power to impose as part of its sentence or fine a requirement that the violator must pay restitution to any person, including the county, if appropriate, injured as a result of the violation. The amount and terms of restitution shall be as determined in the enlightened discretion of the ruling court, office, or tribunal. (Ord. No. 40-100, 12-9-1997) State law reference— Authority of magistrate courts, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-1 et seq.; violations of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-81; trial of misdemeanors upon accusations, O.C.G.A. § 17-7-71; maximum penalties for violations of county ordinances, authority to impose restitution, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60; additional penalties in certain traffic cases, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-73; authority to impose community service as punishment, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-1. Sec. 1-10. - Prosecutions upon citation or accusation authorized. (a) Authority implemented. Any violation of this Code may be tried upon citation without a prosecuting attorney as well as upon accusations. (b) Form of citation. Each citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall have an identifying number by which it shall be filed with the court, shall indicate the identity of the accused and the date of service, and shall be signed by the county or authorized agent who completes and serves it. (c) Commencement of proceeding. Prosecutions for violations of this Code upon citation shall be commenced by the completion, signing, and service of a citation by any agent of the county who is authorized by the board of commissioners to issue citations. A copy of the citation shall be personally served upon the accused, and the original shall promptly be filed with the court. (d) Limitations on arrest. No person shall be arrested prior to the time of trial, except for violations of county ordinances prohibiting public drunkenness, disorderly conduct, or loitering, or as specifically authorized by any provision of this Code or any county ordinance. (e) Exception for failure to appear. Any defendant who fails to appear for trial shall be arrested thereafter on the warrant of the magistrate and required to post a bond for his future appearance. (Ord. No. 30-400(1), 3-12-1985) State law reference— Authority for ordinances implementing prosecutions upon citation and accusation, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63; proceedings relating to citation arrest or accusations, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-262. Sec. 1-11. - Fees established by resolution. Fees for permits, licenses, and other county services shall be as established from time to time by resolution of the board of commissioners and set forth in the separate fee schedule adopted and maintained by the county. A copy of the fee schedule is available for inspection and copying in the office of the county clerk. Sec. 1-12. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are substantially the same as ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-13. - Altering this Code, ordinance or other public document. (a) Altering this Code. It shall be unlawful for any person in the county to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the county to be misrepresented thereby. (b) Altering other public documents. It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, mutilate, or in any other manner alter any ordinance book or minute book, or any notice posted by the county for the benefit of the public, or any other document or record of the municipal government of the county. Sec. 1-14. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any rates, fees or charges consistent with this Code; (2) Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds for the county or any evidence of the county's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the county; (3) Any ordinance consistent with this Code prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, such as prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic or limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones; (4) Any ordinance consistent with this Code fixing salaries of officials, officers or employees of the county; (5) Any budget ordinance or appropriation ordinance; any ordinance levying any tax; (6) Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance or resolution to any person; (7) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the county; (8) Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the county; (9) Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; (10) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the county; (11) Any ordinance establishing or changing the boundary of the county; and (12) Any ordinance regulating zoning or subdividing in the county. All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— County government generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-1. (Back) ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Smoke-free facility. The county provides a smoke-free environment in the county courthouse. The county courthouse is clearly designated by a no smoking sign, and there shall be no smoking in the courthouse. This policy is applicable to all elected officials, employees, and visitors in the courthouse. Secs. 2-2—2-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS
Sec. 2-21. - Composition, authority, duties and procedure. The composition, authority, duties, and procedural rules of the board of commissioners shall be as established in the local acts included in this Code.

div.head: Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; local regulation of alcoholic beverage manufacture, distribution, and sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-40 et seq.; signs advertising alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-3. (Back) ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Licensee means the person to whom the license to sell malt beverages and wine is granted. Malt beverages means beer or ale made in whole or in part from malt. Measured means distance measured by way of the nearest traveled road, street or highway from the front entrance of an outlet to the nearest property line of any involved school, church or other institution. Outlet means any place where malt beverages or wines are offered for sale. Outlet manager means that person who manages or operates the outlet selling malt beverages or wines. Wines means and includes any wines or other beverages made by fermentation and in which the alcoholic content is less than 21 percent by volume. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 2, 1-1-1999) Sec. 4-2. - Privilege; revocation. The sale of beer and wine is a mere privilege and not a right, and the board of commissioners of the county reserves the right to revoke the license of any wholesale or retail dealer at any time, with or without cause, with or without notice, and notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter. State law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-1. Secs. 4-3—4-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSES AND IDENTIFICATION BADGES
Sec. 4-23. - Package sales of malt beverages and wines authorized. The sale of malt beverages and foreign or domestic wines, wholesale or retail, by the package only, it hereby authorized. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 1, 1-1-1999) Sec. 4-24. - License required. (a) No outlet shall engage in the sale of malt beverages or the sale of foreign or domestic wines without first having been issued a license for that outlet by the chairperson of the board of commissioners. (b) No individual shall engage in the sale of malt beverages or the sale of foreign or domestic wines without first having registered with the county sheriff's department and displaying an identification badge issued by the sheriff or the county commissioners' office. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 3, 1-1-1999) State law reference— Dealing in malt beverages at wholesale and retail prohibited without local license, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40; county licensing fees for the sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-41; restriction on county licensing fees for the sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-43; dealing in wine at wholesale and retail prohibited without local license, O.C.G.A. § 3-8-40. Sec. 4-25. - Applications for licenses. (a) An applicant for license to sell malt beverages or wines shall file written application with the county clerk. The application shall contain such information as may be required by the board of commissioners in order to enforce the provisions of this article. (b) The applicant shall publish the application in a local newspaper once a week for four consecutive weeks to coincide with the sheriff's investigation as specified herein. (c) Before a license is issued, the application shall be referred by the clerk to the county sheriff. All applicants must be photographed, fingerprinted, and registered with the sheriff's department. The sheriff shall make an investigation and report back to the clerk within 30 days the following information: (1) Whether the person has ever been convicted of a felony or crime involving moral turpitude or ever been convicted of violating beer, wine or liquor laws of any city, county, state or federal government. (2) Whether the person is of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides. (3) Whether the applicant has ever had an alcoholic beverage license revoked for cause. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 4(a), 1-1-1999) Sec. 4-26. - Applications for identification badges. (a) All individuals, whether owners, employers, servers, or other persons selling malt beverages and/or wines, shall apply at the county commissioners' office for an identification badge. The applicant shall fill out an application giving any information required by the commissioners' office and/or the county sheriff's office. The commissioners' office and/or the county sheriff's office shall make a check of: (1) Whether the person has ever been convicted of a felony or crime involving moral turpitude or whether, to his knowledge, the person applying for such license has ever been convicted of violating beer, wine, or liquor laws of any city, county, state, or federal government. (2) Whether the person is of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides. (3) Whether the applicant has ever had an alcoholic beverage license revoked for cause. (b) The applicant shall be photographed and sign a consent for the background check. A criminal background check on the applicant shall be performed. Within 30 days of the application, the applicant shall be issued an identification badge containing the name of the entity, the applicant's name, the applicant's photograph, the store license number, and the date of the license. Upon the applicant leaving employment, the badge shall be turned in to the county commissioners' office. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 4(b), 1-1-1999) Sec. 4-27. - Prohibitions to licensure. No license for the sale of malt beverages or wines shall be issued to: (1) Any person who cannot provide at least five years of confirmed addresses where the applicant has resided. (2) Any person who is not the owner or a fulltime manager of the outlet applying for the license. (3) Any person who, at the time of his application, has not reached the age of 21 years. (4) A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides. (5) A person who has been convicted of a felony or of any crime involving moral turpitude or to a person who has been convicted of violating any of the laws of any city, county, state or federal government pertaining to alcoholic beverages. (6) A person whose license or badge to sell alcoholic beverages has been revoked for cause. (7) Any law enforcement officer of any municipality or county of the state. (8) Any person who is not eligible for an alcoholic beverage license from the state. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 5, 1-1-1999) State law reference— Discretion and due process regarding grant or suspension of local license, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. Sec. 4-28. - Renewal of licenses and badges. All licenses and badges shall be issued on a calendar year basis and shall be renewable as a matter of course upon payment of the appropriate fee, except where the licensee, badge holder, outlet manager, agent or employee of the licensee has violated any of the terms of this Code, or any state or federal law involving moral turpitude or involving alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 8, 1-1-1999) Sec. 4-29. - Fees. Fees for all applicable licenses shall be set out in a separate fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 8, 1-1-1999) Sec. 4-30. - Reconsideration of refusal to grant or renew license. (a) In the event the board of commissioners should refuse to grant any license or the renewal of a license, the applicant shall have the right to request the board of commissioners to advise in writing the reason for refusal. (b) The applicant shall further have the right, within ten days of receipt of the written reasons for refusal, to request a hearing for reconsideration before the board of commissioners and shall be entitled to present evidence in his behalf as to why the license should be issued. Evidence shall also be admissible to show why the license should not be issued. (c) After hearing, the board of commissioners shall make a finding as to whether the license or license renewal should be granted or denied and, if denied, shall state the reason for denial. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 6, 1-1-1999) Sec. 4-31. - Transfers of license. (a) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages issued hereunder shall be transferable, except upon the death of a licensee, when the license may be transferred to the administrator, executor, or lawful adult heir of the deceased person. If the legal representatives of the deceased licensee cannot meet all the requirements of this article when the time arrives to renew the license, it shall not be renewed. (b) Except as provided herein, any change in the ownership of any entity owning a licensed outlet shall cancel and revoke any license issued hereunder automatically, without the necessity of any hearing. (c) A new license application must be applied for whenever a partnership holding a license admits a new partner to the partnership, not a partner at the time of the original license application. (d) When a partnership holding a license loses the license as a result of the provisions of this section, upon filing an application for a new license, the partnership may continue to operate under the terms of the prior license until the new application is approved or denied by the board of commissioners; provided, however, that no continued operation shall be authorized until the new application for license is made and the required fees paid to the county. Sec. 4-32. - Change in status. When a change occurs: (1) In the relationship of any person; (2) In the status of any property or license; (3) In payment of rents, ownership of the lease, or building or land on which the outlet is located; (4) In ownership or management; (5) In any loss or damage to goods which results in a claim against an insurance policy; (6) In the division of profits; (7) In any division of net or gross sales for any purpose whatsoever; and (8) In facts stated or claimed in any application or report herein required; a sworn statement of the change in all material facts relating thereto shall be filed with the county clerk and failure to do so within five days after the change shall, unless the time limit is extended for good cause, be reason for cancellation of a license granted pursuant to the provisions of this article. Sec. 4-33. - Display of license; separate outlet licenses. Each outlet licensed by the county hereunder shall display the license prominently at all times at the outlet for which the license is issued. A separate license must be issued for each outlet of sale and a separate application must be made for each outlet. State law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-3. Sec. 4-34. - Suspension and revocation. (a) Violation and seizure. The county sheriff may seize and retain the license or badge of a licensee, outlet manager, agent, or employee of the licensee or holder of an identification badge if: (1) At any time it should appear that the licensee, outlet manager, agent or employee of the licensee or the holder of an identification badge has violated this article or any other applicable provisions of this Code, or any state or federal law involving moral turpitude or pertaining to alcoholic beverages; (2) For any reason the outlet should become a public nuisance; (3) It should appear that the application contained known false information; or (4) It appears necessary for the public safety, health and welfare. (b) Request for hearing. Any person whose license or badge, or both, is seized by the sheriff shall have the right, within ten days from seizure, to file a written request to the board of commissioners requesting a hearing before the board and reinstatement of the license or badge. (c) Representation by counsel. At such hearing it shall be the burden of the county to introduce evidence showing the grounds upon which the license or badge was seized. The licensee or badge holder shall also have the right to be represented by counsel and to present evidence in his behalf. (d) Outcome of hearing. Following the hearing, the board of commissioners shall reinstate the badge or license, if the board deems it appropriate, or suspend the license or badge for 30 days for the first offense, suspend the license or badge for 60 days for the second offense, or permanently revoke the license or badge for the third violation. If the license or identification badge is suspended or revoked permanently, the finding shall include the reason therefor. (e) Suspension. During suspension or revocation of a license, there shall be no alcoholic beverages on the premises unless padlocked. (f) Fines and penalties. Any action by the board of commissioners as a result of violation of this article, including issuance of citations, assessment of fines and penalties, nuisance abatement, and license and badge suspensions or revocations shall not be construed as impeding or preventing state prosecution if the violation is also prohibited by and a violation of state law. (Ord. No. 10-125, §§ 7, 8, 1-1-1999) Secs. 4-35—4-56. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS
Sec. 4-57. - Sanitary condition required for premises. The licensee shall keep the premises clean, and in proper sanitary condition, and in full compliance with provisions and regulations governing the conditions of premises used for the storage and sale of food for human consumption and as provided by the rules and regulations of the county board of health. Sec. 4-58. - Inspections. Any officials that may be authorized by the board of commissioners including, but not by way of limitation, the county's sheriff and deputy sheriffs, other law enforcement officers, county code enforcement officers, and the county's fire chief or his designees shall have the authority to inspect the outlet and premises licensed under this article during the hours when the outlet is open for business. These inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this article and state law. This section is not intended to limit the authority of any other city, county, state, or federal officials to conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of law. Sec. 4-59. - Responsibility of employer. The licensee is responsible for the conduct or actions of his employees while in his employment. It shall be the duty of the licensee hereunder to maintain a copy of this article at the outlet and to instruct each and every employee engaged in the sale or handling of alcoholic beverages of the terms hereof. Sec. 4-60. - Prohibited sales and consumption. (a) No holder of a license or identification badge, authorizing the sale of malt beverages or wines in the county, nor any outlet manager, agent or employee of the licensee shall sell any malt beverage or wine except in the original container in which said malt beverage or wine was received from the distributor or sell, offer for sale, possess or license the consumption on the licensed premises of any liquor or other alcoholic beverage or drugs, the sale or possession of which is not authorized by law. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on the premises licensed for the sale of malt beverages or wine by the package and it shall be unlawful for any licensee by the package to open for, or break the package for, a purchaser or permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 6(a), (h), 1-1-1999) State law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-26. Sec. 4-61. - Conduct on licensed premises restricted. No holder of a license or identification badge, authorizing the sale of malt beverages or wines in the county, nor any outlet manager, agent or employee of the licensee shall allow any disorderly conduct, gambling, or breach of the peace on the premises of the outlet. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 6(a), (g), 1-1-1999) Sec. 4-62. - Time of sale restricted. No holder of a license or identification badge, authorizing the sale of malt beverages or wines in the county, nor any outlet manager, agent or employee of the licensee shall sell or permit sale of any malt beverage or wine after 12:00 a.m., midnight or until 7:00 a.m. of the following day during the week and from 12:00 a.m., midnight on Saturday until 7:00 a.m. on the following Monday. No alcoholic beverage may be present on the premises unless padlocked during the hours this establishment is open for regular business. (Ord. No. 10-125, § 6(a), (i), 1-1-1999) State law reference— Sunday sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7; sale on Sunday and election days, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. Sec. 4-63. - Location restrictions. (a) No business licensed hereunder shall be operated within 100 yards of any church or within 200 yards of any school building, educational building, school grounds, or college campus; and no distilled spirits, beer, or wine shall be sold or delivered, or offered for sale or delivery, within such limits. (b) No alcoholic beverages shall be sold or delivered, or offered for sale or delivery within 100 yards of an alcoholic treatment center located in the unincorporated area of the county and owned or operated by the state, the county, or any municipal government. (c) No person knowingly and intentionally may sell any alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises within 100 yards of any housing authority property, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. (d) Malt beverages and wine shall be sold exclusively in a building or storehouse that is licensed hereunder and separate and distinct from any residence or living quarters. (e) For purposes of this section, distances shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground. State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Sec. 4-64. - Sale to intoxicated persons. No licensee shall permit on the licensed premises the sale, barter, exchange, giving, providing or furnishing alcoholic beverages to any person who is in a state of noticeable intoxication. State law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-22. Sec. 4-65. - Adulteration of product. No licensee shall add to the contents of a bottle or refill an empty bottle or in any other manner misrepresent the quantity, quality, or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. State law reference— Adulteration or misbranding of alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 51-1-24. Secs. 4-66—4-88. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - UNDERAGE PERSONS
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- State Law reference— Sale to underage persons prohibited, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-23, 3-3-23.1; restrictions on employment of underage persons, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-24. (Back) Sec. 4-89. - Sales prohibited. Except as otherwise authorized by law, no licensee shall sell or permit to be sold alcoholic beverages to any person under the legal drinking age as prescribed by state law. Sec. 4-90. - Presence on licenses premises restricted. No licensee hereunder shall permit any person under the legal drinking age as prescribed by state law to be in, frequent, or loiter about the licensed premises unless this person is accompanied by a parent, legal guardian, or custodian; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to persons who are employees of the licensee. Sec. 4-91. - Proof of age required. All licensees shall require and properly check identification to ensure an underage person is not sold, served, or has in his possession alcoholic beverages while in a licensed establishment. The term "identification," in this section, means any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, or the person's photograph, and giving the person's date of birth, and including, but without being limited to, a passport, military identification card, driver's license, or state department public safety identification card. Proper identification shall not include a birth certificate. Secs. 4-92—4-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PRIVATE CLUBS
Sec. 4-111. - Definitions; permitted activities. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Private club is defined as a business or social organization catering to and allowing access only to persons who have been granted membership in said business or organization in accordance with the rules established by said business or organization. (b) Permitted activities. It shall be legal for private clubs for there to be music, dancing and live entertainment. (Ord. No. 10-300, §§ 1, 3, 12-14-1982) Sec. 4-112. - Criminal background history required. Before any private club shall operate in the county it shall obtain a business registration as required in chapter 10 of this Code. Before issuing any such business registration, the sheriff's department will, within 30 days of the date of the application for registration, investigate the background of all applicants and provide a report back to the chairperson of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 10-300, § 2, 12-14-1982) Sec. 4-113. - Registration holder responsible for the club. The person in whose name the business registration is issued will be responsible for the operation of the private club and shall be deemed the manager and operator of the registered private club. (Ord. No. 10-300, § 2, 12-14-1982) Sec. 4-114. - Authority and duty regarding alcoholic beverages. (a) Private clubs registered within the unincorporated areas of the county shall be bound by and abide by all county zoning ordinances and restrictions. They shall be governed by applicable state, federal and local laws, including, but not by way of limitation, regulations regarding the sale, dispensing, and delivery of any alcoholic beverages. (b) Private clubs shall be allowed to sell beer, malt beverages and wine for consumption on the premises, but no beer, malt beverages or wine shall be sold or in any manner dispensed or delivered between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Monday through Friday nights and between Saturday, 12:00 a.m., midnight and 7:00 a.m. on the following Monday. (c) The tables, counters, or other places from which beer, malt beverages and wine are usually served within the registered private club must be cleared of all glasses, bottles, cans or containers by 2:30 a.m. each Monday through Friday and by 12:00 a.m., midnight on Saturday night. (Ord. No. 10-300, § 4, 12-14-1982) Sec. 4-115. - Inspections. Private clubs shall be subject to inspection by all county and state law enforcement officers. The county sheriff's department shall have access to the premises of the private club at any time and, in the event key cards are issued to the members of the private club, the sheriff and deputy sheriffs shall be provided current key cards as they may require to gain access to the private club for the purpose of inspecting the club, enforcing all applicable provisions of this Code, and enforcing all applicable state and federal laws. (Ord. No. 10-300, § 5, 12-14-1982) Sec. 4-116. - Telephone required. All private clubs shall have on the premises a telephone available to its members. The number of the telephone, required by this section shall be provided to the county sheriff's department. The telephone shall be kept operational so long as the private club continues to operate. (Ord. No. 10-300, § 6, 12-14-1982) Secs. 4-117—4-145. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - EXCISE TAX
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (3) --- State Law reference— Local excise taxes on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; excise taxes on malt beverages to be paid by wholesale dealer, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-81; prohibition on requirement for markings on beverage containers regarding excise taxes, O.C.G.A. § 35-5-82; local excise taxes on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-8-60. (Back) Sec. 4-146. - Taxes levied; payment. (a) No beer shall be sold in the county by any wholesaler or retailer unless and until a tax of $0.05 for each can or bottle containing 12 ounces, or proportionately thereof, so as to graduate the tax on bottles, cans, kegs and barrels or various sizes, has been paid. (b) No wine shall be sold in the county by any wholesaler or retailer unless and until a tax of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter has been paid. (c) Every wholesaler is charged with the duty of paying the excise taxes on beer and wine provided for in this section. The taxes shall be paid on or before the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the beverages are sold or disposed of within the county by the wholesale dealer. (d) Each licensee shall file a report with the county clerk monthly itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact qualities of malt beverages, by size and type of container, sold during the month within the county.

div.head: Chapter 6 - ANIMALS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abandoned animal, means any animal considered abandoned under the following conditions: (1) Any animal placed upon public property or within a public building and left unattended or uncared for; (2) Any animal placed upon private property of another without the express permission of the owner, custodian, or tenant and left unattended or uncared for; or (3) Any animal left on the property of the owner or custodian of such animal for more than 36 hours unattended and without food and water. Adequate food and water means food and water that is sufficient in amount and appropriate for the particular type of animal to prevent starvation, dehydration, or a significant risk to the animal's health from a lack of food or water. Animal means any description of vertebrate, excluding Homo Sapiens. Animal control, animal control officer, and animal control officers mean designated employees or officers of the county. Animal establishment means any pet shop, kennel, grooming shop, auction, performing animal exhibition or other facility engaged in the handling of animals, excluding licensed veterinarians and veterinary clinics and hospitals. Animal nuisance means an animal shall be considered a nuisance if it: (1) Damages, soils, defiles, or defecates on private property (other than the property of the owner of the animal), or public property and recreational areas; (2) Causes unsanitary, dangerous, or offensive conditions; (3) Causes a disturbance by excessive barking or other noisemaking; (4) Attacks or interferes with persons on public or private property, unless the animal is a guard dog actively performing its duties while confined to the property of the owner or responsible person; (5) Chases vehicles; (6) Attacks other animals; or (7) Runs uncontrolled. Animal shelter means any facility operated by any governmental entity, humane society, or other organization for the purpose of impounding or harboring seized, stray, homeless, abandoned, or unwanted dogs, cats, and other animals held under the authority of this chapter or state law. At large means any animal off the premises of the owner of the animal and is not under the control of a responsible person. Auctions mean any place or facility where animals are regularly bought, sold or traded, except for those facilities otherwise defined in this chapter. Individual sales of animals by owners are not auctions as herein defined. Cruelty means every act, omission or neglect whereby unjustifiable pain, suffering, maiming or death may be caused or permitted to any animal as defined in this section. Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: (1) Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property; or (2) Aggressively bites, attacks, or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. Dog control officer means an individual selected by the board of commissioners to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Fowl means any warm-blooded, feathered, flying or non-flying animals. Humane manner means care of an animal to include, but not to be limited to, safety, adequate heat, ventilation, sanitary shelter, wholesome fresh food, and access to fresh, clean, wholesome water at all times, consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species and breed. Kennel means any premises wherein any person engaged in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, letting for hire, training for a fee or selling animals. Livestock means any animal that has hooves. Neutered or spayed means an animal that was surgically made to be incapable of sexual reproduction. Owner means any person who has title to or the right to possession of an animal, including, but not limited to, the caretaker or custodian of any animal or person harboring or having control of an animal. An animal is deeded in a person's possession if it is fed or sheltered for three consecutive days or more. Pet means any animal kept for pleasure, excluding livestock. Pet shop means any person engaged in the business of buying or selling two or more species of live animals with the intent that they be kept as pets. Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that without provocation bites a human being on public or private property. Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog, potentially dangerous, or vicious dog while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence, or structure, suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape whether from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. Records of an appropriate authority mean records of any state, county, or municipal law enforcement agency; records of any county or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state, or local court; or records of a dog control officer provided for in this article. Responsible person means any accountable human being. Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. Under control means any animal that is confined by fence, pen, cage, electronic device, chain, leash or secure enclosure to the premises of its owner, of sufficient strength to prevent it from escaping from the premises of its owner, any person owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of any animal subject to this chapter. This definition is intended to embrace any person who is a custodian. Veterinary clinic or veterinary hospital means any clinic or hospital operated by a licensed veterinarian. Vicious dog means any dog that: (1) Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation after the owner has notice that the dog has previously bitten or attacked or endangered the safety of a human being; or (2) Is owned, possessed, kept, harbored, trained, or maintained for the purpose of fighting. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-1, 4-9-1991; Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-2, 10-11-1994) State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-21, 4-8-41. Sec. 6-2. - Administration. The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by animal control and by the county sheriff's department. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-80, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-3. - Right of entry. (a) The animal control officers, sheriff's deputies and other enforcement officers of the county are hereby authorized to enter upon any premises or parcel of land for the purpose of seizing and impounding any animal found therein or thereon to be in violation of this chapter, including, but not limited to, an animal that has bitten a person within ten days. (b) Animal control may take all necessary steps to remove any animal locked in a closed vehicle if the animal is subject to danger of injury due to temperature. The operator of the vehicle will be charged with cruelty to animals as defined in this chapter. No injunction or claim for damages may be placed against the animal control or its officers for this action. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-82, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-4. - Interference. No person shall interfere with or hinder animal control or any officer in the performance of their duty or seek to release any animal in the custody of animal control, except as herein provided. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-81, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-5. - Summons. Representatives of animal control and officers of the county sheriff's department are hereby authorized to issue a summons to any person for violation of any provision of this chapter. The summons shall be in a form approved by the county magistrate court, shall designate the offense charged and shall require the person so charged to appear before the county magistrate court on a date certain to answer the charges therein contained. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-83, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-6. - Use of equipment authorized. Animal control is authorized to employ any equipment it deems necessary to enforce the provisions of this chapter, including, but without limitation, make available humane box traps, and animal control may, subject to conditions it may determine, loan or lease traps or other equipment to private persons, residing in the county for the purpose of preventing nuisances resulting from animals at large. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-85, 10-11-1994) Secs. 6-7—6-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-31. - Cruelty to animals. It shall be unlawful for any person, either by commission or omission to: (1) Confine or transport an animal in any other than a humane manner; (2) Overdrive, overload, overwork, torture, beat, mutilate, kill needlessly, carry or contain in a vehicle in an inhumane manner, or otherwise mistreat any animal; (3) Fail to provide any animal with proper food consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species and breed; (4) Fail to provide any animal with access to shelter adequate to protect it from all types of weather, 24 hours daily; (5) Fail to provide any animal access to good and wholesome fresh water at all times; (6) Fail to provide necessary veterinary care; (7) Knowingly or willingly permit or aid in the release of any animal on any property with the intention of abandoning the animal; (8) Intentionally poison any animal; (9) Allow any animal to be kept in unsanitary conditions; or (10) Allow or promote any fight between animals, or to allow or permit any such fight in or upon any premises in such person's possession or under such person's control. (Ord. No. 20-150, §§ 5-42, 5-50, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-32. - Animals locked in vehicles. Animal control may take all necessary steps to remove any animal locked in a closed vehicle if the animal is subject to danger of injury due to the temperature. The operator of the vehicle will be charged with cruelty to animals as defined in this chapter. No injunction or claim for damages may be placed against the animal control or its officers for this action. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-82, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-33. - Removal of animals; costs and fees. (a) It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to remove any animal suspected of being mistreated by the owner, from the property of the owner, if the officer deems it hazardous to the animal's welfare to leave the animal under the care of said owner. (b) The cost of any veterinary fees, impounding fees, and transport fees are to borne by the owner of the animal. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-50(b), (c), 10-11-1994) Secs. 6-34—6-54. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DOGS AND CATS
Sec. 6-55. - Nuisance prohibited. An animal owners' premises shall be maintained in such a manner as not to constitute either a private nuisance to adjoining property owners of a nuisance to the public in general. Pens or enclosures in which animals are confined or maintained shall at all times be kept and maintained in a proper, clean, and sanitary condition so they are kept free from offensive odors which would disturb any person residing within a reasonable distance of the premises. The animals themselves shall be restrained in such a fashion that they shall not disturb such persons by making noise. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-40, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-56. - Confinement required. (a) In any city that has adopted these provisions and contracted for county enforcement of them, the owner of a dog or cat residing within any city limit boundaries in any platted subdivision in which the average lot size is two acres or less, or in any mobile home park, shall confine the dog or cat in a secure enclosure by a chain or leash affixed to the animal's collar and attached to some substantial stationary object adequate to prevent the dog or cat from running at large. (b) It shall further be the duty of any owner or keeper of any dog or cat regardless of the size of the owner's lot or property, to keep the dog or cat under such control so as to: (1) Prevent the animal from becoming a danger to persons or property at any location, or trespassing upon another person's property without that person's permission. (2) Prevent such animal from running at large upon the streets, roads, sidewalks, alleys, parks, or other public places. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-42(a), 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-57. - Females in heat. Every female dog or cat in heat shall be confined in a building or secure enclosure or in a veterinary clinic or hospital or in a kennel or under control in such a manner that such female dog or cat cannot come into contact with a male dog or cat, except for intentional breeding purposes. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-42(b), 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-58. - Hunting dogs. Hunting dogs in the custody of persons hunting in accordance with state game and fish department laws, rules, and regulations are exempt from these mandates. The owners of such dogs shall be civilly liable for any damage occasioned by the actions of their dogs. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-42(d), 10-11-1994) Secs. 6-59—6-89. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - FOWL AND OTHER ANIMALS
Sec. 6-90. - Running at large prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person owning, or having control of any chickens, ducks, horses, cows, goats, pigs or any other type of animal, livestock or other fowl within the county to permit them to run at large or be a menace or nuisance to such person's neighbors or the public in general. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-41, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-91. - Maintenance of enclosures. Any pastures, pens, stalls, or other enclosures for fowl or farm-type or other large animals shall at all times be kept and maintained in a proper, clean, and sanitary condition, consistent with the needs of the animals involved. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-42(c), 10-11-1994) Secs. 6-92—6-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - RABIES CONTROL
Sec. 6-111. - Adoption of state regulations. All applicable rules and regulations of the state department of human resources pertaining to rabies control and vaccination are incorporated herein by reference as though fully set forth in this chapter. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-31(a)(2), 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-112. - Vaccination required. All dogs and cats over four months of age within the county shall have their animals inoculated for the prevention of rabies. No person shall own, keep or harbor any dog or cat within the county unless the dog or cat is vaccinated, as herein provided. (Ord. No. 20-150, §§ 5-3, 5-31(a), 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-113. - Rabies reporting. (a) Every veterinarian shall report promptly to the state department of human resources and the county animal control all cases of rabies in animals treated by such veterinarian, giving the name and address of the owner. Every veterinarian shall also report the names and addresses of the owner of any animals bitten by such rabid animal, so far as known. (b) Any person who knows that an animal, domestic or wild, is rabid or suspects an animal of having rabies, or knows that an animal has been bitten by a rabid animal, shall promptly report such information, to the extent known, to the state department of human resources and the county animal control. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-43(a), (b), 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-114. - Impoundment required. It shall be the duty of the owner, the health department, physicians, hospitals or other person gaining information that any domestic animal has been bitten or is probably infected with rabies, to incarcerate or impound or have the animal incarcerated or impounded in the facility of some competent veterinarian within this county, where the animal shall be held for observation for such period of time as may be reasonably necessary to determine whether the animal is infected with rabies. All costs of this incarceration shall be borne by the owner of the animal. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-43(c), 10-11-1994) Secs. 6-115—6-141. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - DANGEROUS AND VICIOUS DOGS FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Mercedes' Law (vicious dog control), O.C.G.A. § 4-8-40 et seq. (Back) DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-142. - No waiver of immunity or additional liability imposed on county. This article is adopted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. to implement the duties for which the county is responsible under state law. This article shall not be construed to impose any additional duties or liability on the county or on its officers and employees or to waive any immunity that is currently provided by law. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-10, 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-143. - Applicability. (a) A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties shall not be a dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious dog within the meaning of this article. (b) A dog shall not be a dangerous, potentially dangerous, or vicious dig within the meaning of this article if the injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort or was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-1, 4-9-1991) State law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-21, 4-8-41. Secs. 6-144—6-169. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER
Sec. 6-170. - Dog control officer; appointment; duties. The board of commissioners shall appoint a dog control officer who shall have the following duties: (1) To make such investigations and inquiries as may be necessary to identify dangerous dogs and dangerous dog owners within the county, and within the corporate limits of any municipal corporation in the county that contracts with the county for enforcement of this chapter. (2) To classify or reclassify dogs as dangerous dogs or as potentially dogs as defined in this chapter. (3) To follow all post-classification procedures as set out in this chapter and to present evidence at any hearings held pursuant to this code chapter. (4) To issue certificates of registration to owners of dangerous and potentially dangerous dogs as provided in this chapter. (5) To ensure that dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs are properly enclosed in accordance with the terms of this chapter. (6) To confiscate and, in certain cases in accordance with this chapter, destroy certain dangerous and potentially dangerous dogs. (7) To prosecute violations of this chapter as provided by law. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-2, 4-9-1991) State law reference— Jurisdiction and duty of local governments, appointment of dog control officer, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22. Sec. 6-171. - Duty to maintain a copy of state and local laws. The dog control officer shall maintain a copy of all state and local laws applicable to dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs, which records shall be available for inspection by the public during regular business hours. The dog control officer shall not be authorized to interpret these laws nor to give advice to owners. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5.1-11, 10-11-1994) Secs. 6-172—6-195. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - DANGEROUS DOGS
Sec. 6-196. - Investigation. Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within a dog control officer's jurisdiction from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer, or county board of health, the dog control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-4, 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-197. - Classification; notice; hearing. (a) Necessary condition for the enforcement of provisions. As applied to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this section must be carried out as a necessary condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this division against such owners. As applied to the owners of dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this section shall not be an essential element of any crime provided for in this division. (b) Required for notice. When a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog is classified as such, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification. The notice to the owner shall meet the following requirements: (1) The notice shall be in writing and mailed in duplicate by first class mail and by certified mail to the owner's last known address; (2) The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; (3) The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (4) The notice shall state that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the animal control board of county; (5) The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this division on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and (6) The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the animal control board and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the agency. (c) Scheduling of the hearing. When the animal control board receives a request for a hearing as provided herein, it shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time, and place of the hearing, and such notice shall be mailed to the dog owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. (d) Hearing to present evidence. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence and in addition thereto the board of commissioners shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the board of commissioners may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify, or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. (e) Determination of hearing. Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-5, 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-198. - Registration—Potentially dangerous dogs. The dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs when the owner shows the dog control officer sufficient evidence of the following: (1) A proper enclosure sufficient to confine the dog. (2) The posting on the premises where the dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a potentially dangerous dog located on the premises and containing a symbol reasonably calculated to inform children of the presence of the potentially dangerous dog. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-6(a), 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-199. - Same—Dangerous dogs. The dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owners of dangerous dogs when the owner shows the dog control officer sufficient evidence of the following: (1) A proper enclosure sufficient to confine the dog; (2) The posting on the premises where the dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog located on the premises and containing a symbol reasonably calculated to inform children of the presence of the dangerous dog; (3) An insurance policy in the amount of at least $15,000.00 issued by a surety company authorized to do business in the state payable to any person injured by a dangerous dog. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-6(b), 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-200. - Renewal of registration. Certificates of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of the annual renewal of a certificate of registration, a dog control officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is continuing to comply with other provisions of this division. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-6(c), 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-201. - Annual registration fees. The annual fee for the issuance or renewal of a certificate of registration for a potentially dangerous or dangerous dog shall be as established by resolution of the board of commissioners, but not less than $500.00. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-6(c), 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-202. - Duty of owner to notify regarding changes in status. (a) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died, or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the dog control officer with the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. (b) The owner of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the dog control officer's jurisdiction. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the state shall register the dog as required in this division within 30 days after becoming a resident. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves from one jurisdiction to another within the state shall register the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog in the new jurisdiction within ten days after becoming a resident. (Ord. No. 20-125, §§ 5.1-6, 5.1-7, 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-203. - Muzzles and restraints required. (a) Potentially dangerous dog. It is unlawful for the owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. (b) Dangerous dog. It is unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration but will prevent it from biting any person. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-8, 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-204. - Confiscation of dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs. (a) A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if: (1) The owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or bond required herein; (2) The dog is not validly registered as required herein; (3) The dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (4) The dog is outside a proper enclosure as required herein. (b) A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog, if the dog is: (1) Not validly registered as required herein; (2) Not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (3) Outside a proper enclosure in violation of this division. (c) In the event the owner has not complied with the provisions of this division within 20 days of the date the dog was confiscated, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-9, 4-9-1991) Sec. 6-205. - Costs. (a) Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this division and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs. (b) When a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or another person authorized by the dog control officer and placed in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county board of health, the owner of the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall be required to pay all costs incurred by the county as a result of quarantining the dog. (Ord. No. 20-125, § 5.1-9(c), 4-9-1991; Ord. No. 20-150, § 5.1-11, 10-11-1994) Secs. 6-206—6-233. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - VICIOUS DOGS
Sec. 6-234. - Restraint required. It is unlawful for an owner of a vicious dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. Sec. 6-235. - Confiscation. (a) A vicious dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if the dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure or is outside a proper enclosure. (b) Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this division and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs. In the event the owner has not complied with the provisions of this division within 40 days of the date the dog was confiscated, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. Secs. 6-236—6-263. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - IMPOUNDMENT AND DISPOSITION
Sec. 6-264. - Recordkeeping. It shall be the duty of animal control to keep or cause to be kept, accurate and detailed records of the impoundment and disposition of all animals coming into its custody. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-90, 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-265. - Confinement; ownership; disposition. (a) Any animal at large or otherwise in violation of the provisions of this article may be impounded in the animal shelter in a humane manner, for a period of not less than three days. If within such time the animal is not reclaimed by its owner as provided herein the animal shall become the absolute property of the county. (b) The county may convey ownership to any responsible person on such conditions as county animal control may prescribe, or county animal control may humanely destroy the animal. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-70(a), 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-266. - Sick or injured animals. (a) Any impounded animal that is determined to be injured and in pain will be transported promptly to a veterinarian for appropriate medical care. The cost of that care shall be borne by animal control unless the animal is redeemed by the owner, in which event the veterinary costs shall be paid by the owner as provided herein. (b) Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, animal control may refuse to release any animal impounded in the animal shelter for rabies or contagious disease quarantine or for the use as evidence in a criminal prosecution, for such time period as the animal control may determine. (c) Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, animal control may humanely destroy any animal impounded in the animal shelter upon the written opinion of a licensed veterinarian that destruction of the animal is necessary to prevent disease or injury to the animals or to humans due to overcrowding in the animal shelter, the presence or threatened presence of contagious disease, the likelihood of danger or injury to humans or animals, or any other condition. (d) Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, animal control may humanely destroy any animal impounded in the animal shelter when a veterinarian has determined and animal control reasonably believes the animal has sustained an injury or disease that will likely result in maiming, prolonged or severe suffering, or death. (e) In the event an impounded animal must be destroyed as a result of illness or injury prior to the expiration of three days of impoundment, a reasonable effort shall be made to immediately contact the animal's owner, notwithstanding the remaining provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-70(b), (e)—(g), 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-267. - Notice to owner. Following the impoundment of an animal that has displayed on its collar its owner's address, or if the animal is found to be microchipped, and prior to its destruction, animal control shall give the owner seven day's notice of the proposed destruction by certified letter, return receipt requested and by regular mail. If the identification includes the owner's telephone number, animal control may also attempt to notify the owner by telephone. (Ord. No. 20-150, § 5-70(d), 10-11-1994) Sec. 6-268. - Redemption of impounded animals. (a) The owner of an animal impounded in the animal shelter may reclaim the animal upon presenting evidence satisfactory to animal control of compliance with all provisions of this article, and upon payment of fees and charges as hereinafter provided, credited to the account of the animal control. Fees and charges paid pursuant to this article shall not be in lieu of any fine or penalty otherwise provided by law. (b) Owners of impounded animals shall bring proof of vaccination when claiming their animals from the shelter. If the owner is unable to provide proof of vaccination, he may redeem the animal as provided herein, but shall be required to bring proof of rabies vaccination to the shelter within 48 hours of release of the animal.
